{{refimprove|date=April 2013}}
The relationship between '''religion and schizophrenia''' is of particular interest to [[psychiatrists]] because of the similarities between [[religious experience]]s and [[psychosis|psychotic episodes]]; religious experiences often involve [[auditory hallucination|auditory]] and/or [[visual hallucination]]s, and those with schizophrenia commonly report similar hallucinations, along with a variety of beliefs that are commonly recognized by modern medical practitioners as delusional.<ref>{{Cite journal| author=Murray, ED. | author2=Cunningham MG | author3=Price BH | title=The role of psychotic disorders in religious history considered | journal=J Neuropsychiatry Clin Neuroscience | volume=24 | issue=4 | pages=410–26 | doi=10.1176/appi.neuropsych.11090214 | pmid=23224447| year=2012 }}</ref> In general, religion has been found to have "both a protective and a risk increasing effect" for schizophrenia.<ref>Gearing, Robin Edward, Dana Alonzo, Alex Smolak, Katie McHugh, Sherelle Harmon, and Susanna Baldwin. "Association of religion with delusions and hallucinations in the context of schizophrenia: Implications for engagement and adherence." ''Schizophrenia research'' 126, no. 1 (2011): 150-163.</ref>
A common report from those with schizophrenia is some type of religious belief that many medical practitioners consider to be delusional - such as the belief they are divine beings or prophets, that [[God]] is talking to them, they are possessed by demons, etc.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Siddle|first=Ronald |author2=Haddock, Gillian |author3=Tarrier, Nicholas |author4=Faragher, E. Brian |title=Religious delusions in patients admitted to hospital with schizophrenia|journal=Social Psychiatry and Psychiatric Epidemiology|date=1 March 2002|volume=37|issue=3|pages=130–138|doi=10.1007/s001270200005|pmid=11990010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Mohr|first=Sylvia |author2=Borras, Laurence |author3=Betrisey, Carine |author4=Pierre-Yves, Brandt |author5=Gilliéron, Christiane |author6=Huguelet, Philippe|title=Delusions with Religious Content in Patients with Psychosis: How They Interact with Spiritual Coping|journal=Psychiatry: Interpersonal and Biological Processes|date=1 June 2010|volume=73|issue=2|pages=158–172|doi=10.1521/psyc.2010.73.2.158}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Siddle|first=R|author2=Haddock, G |author3=Tarrier, N |author4=Faragher, EB |title=Religious delusions in patients admitted to hospital with schizophrenia.|journal=Social psychiatry and psychiatric epidemiology|date=March 2002|volume=37|issue=3|pages=130–8|pmid=11990010|doi=10.1007/s001270200005}}</ref> Active and adaptive coping skills in subjects with residual schizophrenia are associated with a sound spiritual, religious, or personal belief system.<ref>Shah, Ruchita, et al. "Relationship between spirituality/religiousness and coping in patients with residual schizophrenia." Quality of Life Research 20.7 (2011): 1053-1060.</ref> In a study of patients with schizophrenia that had been previously admitted to a hospital, 24% had what the medical field refers to as religious delusions.
Trans-cultural studies have found that such religious beliefs, which often may not be associated with reality, are much more common in patients with schizophrenia who identify as Christian and/or reside in predominately Christian areas such as Europe or North America.<ref name="Tateyama">{{cite journal |vauthors=Tateyama M, Asai M, Hashimoto M, Bartels M, Kasper S |title=Transcultural study of schizophrenic delusions. Tokyo versus Vienna and Tübingen (Germany) |journal=Psychopathology |volume=31 |issue=2 |pages=59–68 |year=1998 |pmid=9561549 |doi= 10.1159/000029025|url=}}</ref><ref name="Stompe">{{cite journal |vauthors=Stompe T, Friedman A, Ortwein G, Strobl R, Chaudhry HR, Najam N, Chaudhry MR |title=Comparison of delusions among schizophrenics in Austria and in Pakistan |journal=Psychopathology |volume=32 |issue=5 |pages=225–34 |year=1999 |pmid=10494061 |doi= 10.1159/000029094|url=}}</ref> By comparison, patients in Japan much more commonly have delusions surrounding matters of shame and slander,<ref name="Tateyama"/> and in Pakistan matters of paranoia regarding relatives and neighbors.<ref name="Stompe"/>
==Background== {{Main|Schizophrenia}} Schizophrenia is a complex [[Psychosis|psychotic disorder]] in which symptoms include emotional blunting, intellectual deterioration, social isolation, disorganized speech and behavior, delusions, and hallucinations. The causes of schizophrenia are unclear, but it seems that [[heredity|genetics]] play a heavy role, as individuals with a family history are far more likely to suffer from schizophrenia.<ref name="van Os 635–45">{{cite journal|last=van Os|first=J|author2=Kapur, S |title=Schizophrenia.|journal=Lancet|date=2009-08-22|volume=374|issue=9690|pages=635–45|pmid=19700006|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(09)60995-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Picchioni|first=MM|author2=Murray, RM |title=Schizophrenia.|journal=BMJ (Clinical research ed.)|date=2007-07-14|volume=335|issue=7610|pages=91–5|pmid=17626963|doi=10.1136/bmj.39227.616447.BE|pmc=1914490}}</ref> The disorder can be triggered and exacerbated by social and environmental factors, with episodes becoming more apparent in periods of high [[stress (psychological)|stress]]. Neurologists have found that the schizophrenic brain has larger ventricles (fluid-filled cavities) compared to a well brain. This is hypothesized to be due to loss of nerve cells.<ref name="UCLA Newsroom">{{cite web|last1=Page|first1=Dan|title=UCLA Researchers Map How Schizophrenia Engulfs Teen Brains|url=http://newsroom.ucla.edu/releases/UCLA-Researchers-Map-How-Schizophrenia-2701}}</ref> Symptoms usually appear around the onset of early adulthood.<ref name="van Os 635–45"/> It is rare for a child to be diagnosed with schizophrenia, in part because of the difficulty in establishing what erroneous thoughts and beliefs can be attributed to childhood development<ref>{{cite web|last1=McLeod|first1=Saul|title=Egocentrism|url=https://www.simplypsychology.org/preoperational.html|website=simplepsychology.org|accessdate=April 17, 2017}}</ref> and which thoughts and beliefs can be attributed to schizophrenia. With [[psychiatric medication]] (usually [[antipsychotic]]s) and therapy, individuals with schizophrenia can live successful and productive lives.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://psychcentral.com/lib/atypical-antipsychotics-for-schizophrenia/|title=Grohol, John M., Dr. "Atypical Antipsychotics for Schizophrenia." Psych Central. N.p., 17 July 2016. Web. 14 Apr. 2017.|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Role of religion in schizophrenia treatment ==
It has been shown in longitudinal studies that those suffering from schizophrenia have varying degrees of success when religion plays a significant role in their recovery.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mohr|first=S.|title=Toward an Integration of Spirituality and Religiousness Into the Psychosocial Dimension of Schizophrenia|journal=American Journal of Psychiatry|date=1 November 2006|volume=163|issue=11|pages=1952–1959|doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.163.11.1952}}</ref> It would seem that the use of religion can either be a helpful method of coping with the disorder, or it can be a significant hindrance in recovery. Especially for those who are active in a [[religious community]], religion can also be a very valuable tool in coping with the disorder.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Danbolt|first=Lars J.|title=The Personal Significance of Religiousness and Spirituality in Patients With Schizophrenia|journal=International Journal for the Psychology of Religion|date=31 March 2011|volume=21|issue=2|pages=145–158|doi=10.1080/10508619.2011.557009}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Helman|first=DS|title=Recovery from schizophrenia: An autoethnography|journal=Deviant Behavior|date=2018|volume=39|issue=3|pages=380–399|doi=10.1080/01639625.2017.1286174}}</ref> It can be difficult, however, to distinguish if a religious experience is genuine to the spiritual person, or if it is a positive symptom of the illness.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Koenig|first=Harold G.|title=Religion, spirituality and psychotic disorders|url=http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_abstract&pid=S0101-60832007000700013&lng=en&nrm=iso&tlng=en|journal=Archives of Clinical Psychiatry (São Paulo)|volume=34|pages=95–104|doi=10.1590/S0101-60832007000700013|issn=0101-6083|year=2007}}</ref> This is where a skilled and reliable therapist can help. Provided that a [[mental health professional|therapist]] is open to the use of religion in one's treatment, and that the patient is open and receiving said treatment, it is entirely possible to tie religion in with professional therapeutic aids and [[medication]] in order to meet a desirable goal. Those who are involved in their church and are spiritual on a daily basis, while getting psychiatric treatment have reported fewer symptoms and a better quality of life. They learn to see their religion as a source of hope rather than a tormenting reality.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mohr|first=S|author2=Huguelet P |title=The relationship between schizophrenia and religion and its implications for care|journal=Swiss Medical Weekly|url=http://www.smw.ch/docs/pdf200x/2004/25/smw-10322.pdf}}</ref>
== Religion as a trigger for schizophrenia == {{POV|date=April 2017}} Schizophrenia can be triggered by a variety of environmental factors, including significant stress, intensely emotional situations, and disturbing or uncomfortable experiences. It is possible that religion itself may be a trigger for schizophrenia; religious imagery is often very grandiose, and defies commonly held beliefs of what is realistic and natural in the world. Experiencing an intense religious experience may trigger a psychotic episode in those who are vulnerable to them, because religion often requires a believer to suspend their usual idea of what is possible and impossible. This could potentially lead to a psychotic episode due to the shift in realistic thinking; a sufferer may believe that they themselves are [[Deity|religious deities]] or [[Messiah]]s, or that God himself is speaking to the individual. These symptoms may cause violent behavior, either on others or themselves because of taking passages in religious texts literally.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.117.217&rep=rep1&type=pdf|title=The relationship between schizophrenia and religion and its implications for care|first1=Sylvia|last1=Mohr|first2=Philippe|last2=Huguelet|journal=Swiss Med Weekly|year=2004|volume=134|pp=369–376|via=citeseerx.ist.psu.edu|access-date=2017-04-17}}</ref> In some instances, they may also experience more distress-inducing symptoms if they believe that God is using their illness as a punishment. Religion, depending on how the patient views it, can be paralyzing and quite harmful, in that the patient may refuse treatment based on religious beliefs; in certain instances, one might believe that their delusions and hallucinations are actually a divine experience, and therefore deny any treatment. It has been shown that those with schizophrenia who suffer from religious delusions are more religious than those who do not suffer from these delusions.<ref name="Mohr 1095–1103">{{cite journal|last=Mohr|first=Sylvia |author2=Borras, Laurence |author3=Rieben, Isabelle |author4=Betrisey, Carine |author5=Gillieron, Christiane |author6=Brandt, Pierre-Yves |author7=Perroud, Nader |author8=Huguelet, Philippe|title=Evolution of spirituality and religiousness in chronic schizophrenia or schizo-affective disorders: a 3-years follow-up study|journal=Social Psychiatry and Psychiatric Epidemiology|date=11 October 2009|volume=45|issue=11|pages=1095–1103|doi=10.1007/s00127-009-0151-0}}</ref> It has also been shown that those who suffer from religious delusions are less likely to continue long-term treatment.

'''Religious music in Iran''' is rich in melodies and genres. [[Iran]] is a multi cultural land, where various faiths exist. Each faith has its own associated music and ritual.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.iranchamber.com/music/articles/ritual_religious_music.php| title = Ritual and Religious Music in Iran| publisher = Iran Chamber Society | accessdate = 2007-11-16}}</ref> Iranian religious music is defined as the music that has been used in streets, mosques, holy places and on religious occasions.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://iran-daily.com/1385/2768/html/art.htm#s205722| title = Composer Criticizes Religious Music Trend| date = January 26, 2005| accessdate = 2007-11-16 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071018004657/http://iran-daily.com/1385/2768/html/art.htm#s205722 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-10-18}}</ref>
* '''[[Zoroastrian]] religious music in Iran''' * '''[[Islam]]ic religious music in Iran''' ** Noheh and Rozeh Khani ** Sham e Ghariban ** Prayer music ** Iranian Azan The most well-known Iranian performance of [[Adhan|Azan]] dates back to 1955 performed by renowned Iranian religious singer, Rahim Moazenzadeh.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.iran-daily.com/1384/2266/html/art.htm| title = Veteran Muezzin Ill | date = May 4, 2007| accessdate = 2007-11-16| publisher = Iran Daily Newspaper |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071024181751/http://www.iran-daily.com/1384/2266/html/art.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.iran-daily.com/1384/2295/html/panorama.htm| title = Seyyed Rahim Moazzen-Zadeh| date = Jun 11, 2005| accessdate = 2007-11-16| publisher = Iran Daily Newspaper |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071205053015/http://iran-daily.com/1384/2295/html/panorama.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-12-05}}</ref>
*'''[[Christian]] religious music in Iran''' *'''[[Jewish]] religious music in Iran''' *'''[[Bahá'í]] religious music in Iran'''
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
== See also == * [[Music of Iran]] * [[Islamic music]]
[[Category:Iranian music]] [[Category:Religious music]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} The [[Boy Scouts of America]] use many '''Scout Prayers'''.{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} All packs/dens/troops should keep a '''"Prayer Book"'''; one Scout takes it home each week and inscribes in it his own prayer to read out at the end of a meeting.{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}}
Official prayers are widely used by groups that don't use a Prayer Book or when the Prayer Book is not available. Different groups use slight variations of these.{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} This happens from an incorrect teaching of the prayer, an adaptation for a specific country, or other reasons.{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}}
==The Cub Scout Prayer== Used by the [[Cub Scout]] section.{{where|date=December 2012}}
<poem>Help us, oh lord, to serve you day by day To do our duty and to enjoy our play To keep the cub scout promise and to rest Knowing we tried to do our best. Amen.</poem>
Used by the [[Cub Scouts (The Scout Association)|Cub Scouts]] of [[the Scout Association]]:<ref>[http://www.scouthelp.co.uk/The_Cub_Scout_Prayer_-_Prayers ScoutHelp Site]</ref>-
<poem>Help us, dear God, to love thee day by day To do our duty to you and enjoy our play To keep our cub scout promise the best that we can And to do our best always to help our fellow man. Amen.</poem> Several Cub Scout prayers are used in the United States of America.<ref>[http://usscouts.org/scoutduty/sd2gc58.asp Cub Scout Prayers]</ref>
==The Scout Prayer==
Used by the [[Boy Scout|Scout]] section.
<poem>Almighty and everlasting God, By whose grace thy servants are enabled to fight The good fight of faith and ever prove victorious; We humbly beseech thee so to inspire us That we may yield our hearts to thine obedience And exercise our wills on thy behalf. Help us to think wisely, To speak rightly, To resolve bravely, To act kindly, To live purely. Bless us in body and soul And make us a blessing to our comrades. Whether at home or abroad May we ever seek the extension of thy kingdom. Let the assurance of thy presence Save us from sinning, Strengthen us in life and comfort us in death. O Lord our God, accept this prayer We pray to the lord, Amen. </poem>
<poem>Dear Heavenly Father,
Help to keep my honor bright And teach me that integrity of character Is my most priceless possession.
Grant that I may do my best today, And strive to do even better tomorrow.
Teach me that duty is a friend and not an enemy, And help me face even the most disagreeable task cheerfully.
Give me the faith to understand my purpose and life, Open my mind to the truth and fill my heart with love.
I am thankful for all the blessings you have bestowed upon my country. Help me to do my duty to my country and To know that a good nation must be made from good men.
Help me to remember my obligation to obey the Scout Law, And give me understanding, so that it is more than mere words.
May I never tire of the joy of helping other people or Look the other way when someone is in need.
You have given me the gift of a body, Make me wise enough to keep it healthy, That I might serve better.
You are the source of all wisdom, Help me to have an alert mind, Teach me to think, And help me to learn discipline.
In all that I do and in every challenge I face, Help me to know the difference between right and wrong, And lead me in obedience on a straight path to a worthy goal.
Amen. </poem>
==The Scout Law Prayer==
(This prayer is designed to demonstrate the [[Scout Law]])
<poem>Dear Lord, Bless all those everywhere who contribute to shape the hearts, minds and bodies of young people. Let us remember what they have taught and apply it daily.
When facing deceit and dishonesty, let us be Trustworthy. If we see hypocrisy and faithlessness, let us be Loyal. Where disregard of others and mere materialism prevail, let us be Helpful. When we find people in despair, let us be Friendly. In an atmosphere of ill manner, let us be Courteous. Where some measure manliness in brutality and crudeness, let us be Kind. Though lawbreaking and rule-scoffing are common, let us be Obedient. While others grumble and grouch, let us be Cheerful. In an environment blighted by waste and extravagance, let us be Thrifty. When confronted with danger and temptation, let us be Brave. As we see filth and pollution everywhere, let us be Clean. While witnessing impiety, let us remember to be Reverent.
In short, in a world that has for generation after generation lamented the lack of good examples, let us, as Scouts, stand out, grow up, and become real adults.
Amen. </poem>
==The Venturer Prayer==
Used by the [[Venture Scout]] section. <poem> Lord, We thank you for letting us come once again to marvel at your creations. We hope that those in the group who are new to this activity will leave with the same sense of wonder that we always feel as we step into a cave. We treat these activities as fun, but always with a sense of wonder at the thousands of years required to create even the smallest of the features at which we look. Help us to preserve your work, both for ourselves and for future generations of Scouts and Cavers.
Amen.</poem>
==The Rover Prayer==
The rover prayer is based upon the prayer of St [[Ignatius of Loyola]] and was adopted by [[Robert Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell|Baden-Powell]] for use by the [[Rover Scout]] section.
<poem>By the Spirits of the Just, Made perfect in their suffering; Teach us in our turn, O Lord; To serve thee as we ought: To give, and not to count the cost, To fight, and not to heed the wounds, To toil and not to seek for rest To labor and not to ask any reward, Save that of knowing that we do thy will.
Amen.</poem>
==Gilwell Grace==
Originated at [[Gilwell Park]].
<poem>Oh Lord, the giver of all good. We thank thee, for our daily food. May Scouting friends, and Scouting ways. Help us to serve thee all our days. Amen.</poem>
==Philmont Grace== {{Main|Wilderness Grace}}
<poem>For food, for raiment, for life, for opportunity, For friendship and fellowship, We thank thee, O Lord.<ref>[http://www.boyscouttrail.com/content/grace/philmont-560.asp Philmont Grace]</ref></poem>
==Summit Grace== <poem>For this time and this place, For your goodness and grace, For each friend we embrace, We thank thee, O Lord.</poem>
==Order of the Arrow Grace== <poem>For night alone that rests our thought, For quiet dawn that lights our trail, For evening fire that warms and cheers, For each repast that fuels our work, We give thanks, O Lord.</poem>
==See also== * [[Scouting]] * [[Scout Law]] * [[Religion in Scouting]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.boyscouttrail.com/boy-scouts/boy-scout-graces.asp Boy Scout graces] * [http://usscouts.org/reverent/prayers.asp Prayers and Graces] * [http://www.bsatroop91.net/prayer.html A SCOUT’S PRAYER by Lord Baden-Powell]
[[Category:Prayer]] [[Category:Scouting ideals]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Korean name| hangul=서해안배연신굿| hanja=西海岸배연신굿| rr=Seohaean baeyeonsingut| mr=Sŏhaean baeyŏnsingut}} '''Seohaean baeyeonsingut''' is a shamanistic [[exorcism ritual]] that takes place on top of a boat in the Korea's West Coast region. It is performed to the gods to ask for abundant catches of fish at sea. It's South Korea's Important Intangible Cultural Properties 82-2.
July 7 is the day when [[fishermen]] lost at sea can see the [[Big Dipper]], the brightest stars that will help them find their way like a compass. From olden times, Koreans believed that the Big Dipper was the [[constellation]] of stars that controlled the time of space and human lives. That is why humans have prayed for health and happiness in the direction of the Big Dipper. On the night of July 7, popular folklore also has it that two love stars, [[Gyunwoo]] and [[Jiknyu]], meet and form the beautiful galaxy. This is another reason why the exorcism is held on this day.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.arirang.co.kr/Tv2/ALegacy_Archive.asp?PROG_CODE=TVCR0301&view_cont_seq=8&code=St1&sys_lang=Eng|title=Seohaean Baeyeonsingut, Exorcism for Abundant Fishing|date=September 12, 2007|publisher=Arirang TV}}</ref>
Seohaean Baeyeonsingut were performed annually in the villages in [[Haeju]], [[Ongjin County, South Hwanghae|Ongjin]] and the [[Yeonpyeong Island]] of [[Hwanghaedo]], [[North Korea]], with a prayer for peace in the village and a good catch.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nrich.go.kr/eng/info/video_list.jsp?vid=v01_39.jsp|title=Seohaean Baeyeonsingutmit Daedonggut (Baeyeonsingut and Daedonggut of the western coast)|date=September 12, 2007|publisher=National Research Institute of Cultural Heritage}}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The exorcism is performed as a prayer to the gods of the heaven and the sea. It is believed that the rite is more effective if performed by a [[shaman]] ({{lang-ko|[[Mudang]]}}), so it is traditionally performed with one.
==See also== * [[Korean Shamanism]] * [[Shaman]] * [[Korean Culture]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Korea-stub}}
[[Category:Korean culture]] [[Category:Important Intangible Cultural Properties of South Korea]] [[Category:Exorcism]]

{{Infobox given name | name = Shreya | image = | image_size = | caption = | pronunciation = | gender = | meaning = "precious"
"prosperous" | region = Persia and India | language =
[[Avestan]], [[Arabic]] | origin = Indian, Avestan, Arabian | alternative spelling = Sharia | nickname = | variant forms = | related names = Shreya, Shriya, Sharia, Sreya, Shreeya | name day = | derived = Avestan | popularity = | footnotes = }} '''Shreya''' is an Indian and Persian girls name and also has an Arabian background from “Sharia” meaning lattice. The word {{IAST|Shreya}} has several meanings which include "precious", "most beautiful. {{Cite MWSD|śreyas}} The name has a Zoroastrian background as well as Shreya is an Avestan word meaning prosperous. == Notable people == === Shreya === * [[Shreya Dhital]] (born April 12, 1995), Nepalese swimmer. * [[Shreya Ghoshal]] (born March 12, 1984), Indian playback singer. * [[Shreya Narayan]] (born February 22, 1985, Indian actress, model, writer and social worker. === Shriya === * [[Shriya Saran]] (born September 11, 1982), Indian actress and model. === Sriya === * [[Sriya Reddy]] (born April 3, 1983), Indian actress and anchor. == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Zoroastrians]] [[Category: Persian feminine given names]] [[Category: Indian feminine given names]] {{given-name-stub}}

{{Infobox person |image = |name = Swami Ghanananda |birth_place = Senya Beraku, [[Central Region, Ghana|Central Region]], [[Ghana]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1937|9|12|df=yes}} |death_date = {{Death date and age|2016|1|18|1937|9|12|df=yes}} |death_place = |occupation = [[Swami]]
[[Guru-shishya tradition|Śishya]] of [[Swami Krishnananda]] }} '''Swami Ghanananda''' (12 September 1937 – 18 January 2016) was a prominent swami of the indigenous [[Hinduism in Ghana|Hindu community in Ghana]], and is the first{{citation needed|date=July 2014}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.myjoyonline.com/news/2016/february-2nd/guide-kwesi-essel-first-african-hindu-monk-dies.php|title=Ghana News - Swami Saraswati, first African Hindu monk from Ghana, dies|last=Myjoyonline.com|website=www.myjoyonline.com|access-date=2016-06-16}} Hindu swami of African ancestry. He was initiated as a [[swami]] by the late [[Swami Krishnananda]] of India in 1975, and was head the Hindu Monastery of Africa in [[Accra]], Ghana.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/10401741.stm Ghana's unique African-Hindu temple - BBC News] By [[Rajesh Joshi]] ==Biography== ===Early life=== Swami Ghanananda was born in a Senya Beraku village, [[Central Region, Ghana|central region]] of Ghana on 12 September into a native Ghanaian faith, but his parents converted to Christianity. From a very early age he thought about the mysteries of the universe and tried to find the answers in religious texts. ===Journey to India=== Swami Ghanananda then read some books on the Hindu faith and embarked upon a new journey which took him to [[Rishikesh]] in the [[India]]n [[States and territories of India|state]] of [[Uttarakhand]] in northern India. He spent some time there with a spiritual guru who suggested him to open the monastery in Accra. ===First meeting with Swami Krishnananda=== In 1962, Swami Ghanananda moved to Accra and on 24 November, he formed the Divine Mystic Path Society. He then started correspondence courses on the Hindu way of life ([[Sanatana_Dharma#Dharma|Sanatana Dharma]]) with the Divine Life Society of Rishikesh, located in the foothills of the [[Himalaya]]s in northern India, where he first met [[Swami Krishnananda]] of India and became his [[Guru-shishya tradition|śishya]] (disciple), and then in 1975 Swami Krishnananda initiated Swami Ghanananda as a [[swami]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/south_asia/10401741.stm Ghana's unique African-Hindu temple] at [[BBC News]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Ghanananda}} [[Category:Hindu monks|Ghanananda, Swami]] [[Category:Converts to Hinduism|Ghanananda, Swami]] [[Category:Hindu missionaries]] [[Category:Hinduism in Ghana]] [[Category:Ghanaian Hindus]] [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:Ghanaian monks]] [[Category:Ghanaian missionaries]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] {{Hindu-bio-stub}} {{Africa-reli-bio-stub}}

[[File:Temple of Taffeh in Leiden by Paul Garland.jpg|thumb|The Temple of Taffeh in the [[Rijksmuseum van Oudheden]] (Leiden, the Netherlands).]] The '''Temple of Taffeh''' ({{lang-ar|معبد طافا}}) is an [[Ancient Egypt]]ian [[Egyptian temple|temple]] which was presented to the [[Netherlands]] for its help in contributing to the historical preservation of Egyptian antiquities in the 1960s. The temple was built of sandstone<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rmo.nl/actueel/persinformatie/algemene-persfoto%27s/fact-sheet-tempel |language=nl |title=Fact Sheet ‘De tempel van Taffeh’ |author=Selkit Verberk |date= |accessdate=2017-10-27 |publisher=Rijksmuseum van Oudheden}}</ref> between 25 BCE and 14 CE during the rule of the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] emperor [[Augustus]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rmo.nl/english/collection/highlights/egyptian-collection/temple-of-taffeh |title=Temple of Taffeh |publisher=Rijksmuseum van Oudheden |date= |accessdate=2017-10-27}}</ref> It was part of the Roman fortress known as Taphis<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unostamps.nl/subject_save_nubia.htm |title=UNO Stamps |publisher=Unostamps.nl |date= |accessdate=2013-01-02}}</ref> and measures {{convert|6.5|x|8|m|ft}}.<ref>Dieter Arnold, Temples of the Last Pharaohs, Oxford University Press, 1999. p.240</ref> The north temple's "two front columns are formed by square pillars with engaged columns" on its four sides.<ref name="ArnoldTemples">Arnold, Temples of the Last Pharaohs, p.240</ref> The rear wall of the temple interior features a statue niche.
In 1960, in relation to the construction of the [[Aswan Dam|Aswan High Dam]] and the consequent threat posed by its reservoir to numerous<ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/en/activities/173/ The Rescue of Nubian Monuments and Sites], UNESCO</ref> monuments and archeological sites in [[Nubia]] such as the temple of [[Abu Simbel]], [[UNESCO]] made an international call to save these sites.<ref>{{cite web|author=Time Magazine, |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,828111-2,00.html |title=The Pharaoh & the Flood, Friday, Apr. 12, 1963 |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2013-01-02}}</ref><ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/en/activities/172/ Monuments of Nubia-International Campaign to Save the Monuments of Nubia] World Heritage Committee, UNESCO</ref> In gratitude, Egypt assigned several monuments to the countries that replied to this plea in a significant way, including the Netherlands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://portal.unesco.org/culture/en/ev.php-URL_ID=24168&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html |title=Unesco |publisher=Portal.unesco.org |date= |accessdate=2013-01-02}}</ref> Adolf Klasens, the director of the Rijksmuseum van Oudheden and a Dutch Egyptologist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saqqara.nl/context/profiles/klasens |title=Adolph Klasens bio |publisher=Saqqara.nl |date= |accessdate=2013-01-02}}</ref> played a part in arranging the agreement where Egypt presented the temple of Taffeh to the [[Rijksmuseum van Oudheden]] in [[Leiden]], the [[Netherlands]].
This building is constructed from 657 blocks weighing approximately 250 tons.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schrijver|first=Elka|date=1979|title=The Netherlands|jstor=879668|journal=The Burlington Magazine|volume=121|issue=915|pages=402–399}}</ref> After arriving in 1971, it was reconstructed in a new wing of the National Museum of Antiquities (Rijksmuseum van Oudheden) in Leiden, Netherlands. The new structure was designed in such a way that the Dutch weather would not affect the stone, that natural light would illuminate the temple and that visitors could see the temple before having to pay for admission.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/48-hours-in/48-hours-in-leiden-netherlands-523843.html|title=US|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-02-24|language=en-GB}}</ref> There was also an effort to replace a minimum number of damaged stones.
A Greek inscription and a [[Christian cross]] remain carved into its walls.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sacred-destinations.com/netherlands/leiden-museum-of-antiquities.htm |title=Sacred destinations |location=Leiden, South Holland, Netherlands |publisher=Sacred destinations |date= |accessdate=2013-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051228231704/http://www.sacred-destinations.com/netherlands/leiden-museum-of-antiquities.htm |archivedate=2005-12-28 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== The four temples donated to countries assisting the relocation are: * [[Temple of Debod]] ([[Madrid]], [[Spain]]) * [[Temple of Dendur]] ([[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], [[New York City|New York]], [[United States]]) * Temple of Taffeh ([[Rijksmuseum van Oudheden]] in [[Leiden]], the [[Netherlands]]) * [[Temple of Ellesyia]] ([[Museo Egizio]], [[Turin]], [[Italy]])
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{commons category|Temple of Taffeh}} * [http://www.siteclx.nl/rmo/index.php/do-collection/language-en/sub-egyptischetempel Official Site]

{{Speciesbox | image = Thuja standishii.jpg | image_caption = ''Thuja standishii'' foliage and cones
upper side left, under side right | status = NT | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = {{Cite journal | author = Carter, G. | author2 = Farjon, A. | last-author-amp = yes | title = ''Thuja standishii'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2013 | page = e.T42264A2968225 | date = 2013 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/42264/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2013-1.RLTS.T42264A2968225.en | access-date = 14 December 2017}} | genus = Thuja | species = standishii | authority = ([[George Gordon (botanist)|Gordon]]) [[Elie-Abel Carrière|Carr.]] }} '''''Thuja standishii''''' ('''Japanese thuja'''; ''nezuko'', ''kurobe'') is a species of [[thuja]], an [[evergreen]] [[conifer]]ous [[tree]] in the cypress family [[Cupressaceae]]. It is native to southern [[Japan]], where it occurs on the islands of [[Honshū]] and [[Shikoku]]. It is a medium-sized tree, reaching 20–35 m tall and with a trunk up to 1 m diameter. The foliage forms in flat sprays with scale-like [[leaf|leaves]] 2–4 mm long, matte green above, and with narrow white [[stomata]]l bands below. The [[conifer cone|cones]] are oval, yellow-green ripening red-brown, 6–12 mm long and 4–5 mm broad (opening to 8 mm broad), with 6–10 overlapping scales. It is an important timber tree in Japan, grown in [[forestry]] [[plantation]]s for its durable, waterproof, attractively scented [[wood]]. There is some evidence that extracts of Thuja standishii have biological activity. It contains a compound called [[Standishinal]] which has shown relatively potent effects on the [[Aromatase]] enzyme. It acts as an inhbitor, thus decreasing the synthesis of [[Estradiol]] in the human body. This compound has been used in research and derivatives of it have shown even stronger inhibition of Aromatase. ==References== {{Morefootnotes|article|date=October 2018}}{{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0040-4039(99)01191-0 |title=Standishinal, a novel carbon skeletal diterpene from the bark of Thuja standishii (Gord.) Carr |journal=Tetrahedron Letters |volume=40 |issue=35 |pages=6419–6422 |year=1999 |last1=Ohtsu |first1=Hironori |last2=Iwamoto |first2=Manabu |last3=Ohishi |first3=Hirofumi |last4=Matsunaga |first4=Shunyo |last5=Tanaka |first5=Reiko }} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.bmc.2007.01.031 |pmid=17287126 |title=Synthesis of dl-standishinal and its related compounds for the studies on structure–activity relationship of inhibitory activity against aromatase |journal=Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry |volume=15 |issue=7 |pages=2736–2748 |year=2007 |last1=Katoh |first1=Takahiro |last2=Akagi |first2=Taichi |last3=Noguchi |first3=Chie |last4=Kajimoto |first4=Tetsuya |last5=Node |first5=Manabu |last6=Tanaka |first6=Reiko |last7=Nishizawa (Née Iwamoto) |first7=Manabu |last8=Ohtsu |first8=Hironori |last9=Suzuki |first9=Noriyuki |last10=Saito |first10=Koichi }} ==External links== *[http://www.conifers.org/cu/th/standishii.htm Gymnosperm Database - ''Thuja standishii''] {{Cupressaceae}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q1683350}} [[Category:Thuja|standishii]] [[Category:Endemic flora of Japan]] [[Category:Trees of Japan]] [[Category:Five sacred trees of Kiso]] [[Category:Least concern plants]] [[Category:Least concern biota of Asia]]
